title: Longevity
content: My clinical interest is longevity, which is a function of lifespan and healthspan.

title: Lifespan and Healthspan
content: Lifespan is pretty easy to define. It’s the number of years you live. Healthspan is intuitively obvious, but a bit harder to define. For simplicity, let’s agree that healthspan is a measure of how well, not necessarily long, you live.

title: The Science of Longevity
content: I’m in the (very slow and time consuming) process of writing a book on this topic, which is really two books in one—the science of longevity and the “art” of it, the latter being a nuanced discussion about how one applies said science (most of it in animals) to the species of interest—people.

title: Healthspan
content: Healthspan, in its most distilled form, is about preserving three elements of life as long as possible: Brain—namely, how long can you preserve cognition (i.e., executive function, processing speed, short-term memory) Body—specifically, how long can you maintain muscle mass, functional movement and strength, flexibility, and freedom from pain “Spirit”—how robust is your social support network and your sense of purpose

title: Movement
content: In this post, I’d like to focus on one subset of healthspan: item #2—movement.

title: The Hack
content: Evolutionary biology can, at times, provide a helpful framework for longevity. But many things I (and others) argue are necessary for longevity don’t really have an obvious foundation in evolutionary biology. Enter “the hack.”

title: Exercise Hack: Movement Preparation
content: Let’s focus on one hack, in particular—movement preparation.

title: Introduction
content: In this article, Peter Attia talks about his experience with Jesse Schwartzman, a movement expert, and how they decided to create a video of the warm-up sequence Jesse put him through. Peter emphasizes the importance of functional movement and reconnecting with childhood movement patterns to maintain muscle mass, move functionally, and prevent pain and injury. He also differentiates between the stupid stuff he does and the deliberate things one needs to do to overcome our civilized environment for longevity. Lastly, he thanks Elliot Stern and Kelly Choi for producing and editing the videos.

title: Experience in Health and Wellness Industry
content: Jesse now has over 10 years of experience in the health and wellness industry in one on one personal training, nutritional counseling, health coaching, group workshops, and the corporate setting.

title: Certification and Training Experience
content: Jesse previously trained clients at the highest certification level at Equinox Fitness Clubs, and managed Equinox’s most elite trainers and exclusive clientele in the Tier 4 Program at the “E” club.
